<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace:
```c
bool
MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                               void *block,
                               size_t block_size)
{
  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (block != NULL || block_size == 0);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= block_size);
  if (NULL != block)
  {
    const size_t block_offset = mp_ptr_diff_ (block, pool->memory);
    mhd_assert (mp_ptr_le_ (pool->memory, block));
    mhd_assert (pool->size >= block_offset);
    mhd_assert (pool->size >= block_offset + block_size);
    return (pool->pos ==
            ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (block_offset + block_size));
  }
  return false; /* Unallocated blocks cannot be resized in-place */
}
```

explanation: No calls to any of the string.h functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (e.g., memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) are present in this function. The function only uses assertions, pointer-difference helpers (mp_ptr_diff_), pointer-order check (mp_ptr_le_), and a rounding macro (ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE). The pointer arithmetic is guarded by asserts that check block != NULL, block_offset bounds, and pool->size >= block_offset + block_size, and there is an explicit check of block being within pool->memory. Therefore there are no direct uses of string.h functions to examine for out‑of‑bounds accesses. If any of the called macros/functions (mp_ptr_diff_, mp_ptr_le_, ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE, or mhd_assert) were to internally invoke string.h functions, those expansions should be inspected, but nothing in this function text itself matches the set of string.h calls covered by Rule 21.17.
